English/25-10-06.content:
The Opportunity
The lock clicked as my dad turned the key. He opened the door and I took my bag up to my room to unpack. When I was done I slumped back onto my bed. The tiredness washed over me and I sat up to stop myself from nodding off.
“Sleepover” is a weird word. There had been no sleep. The weight of being awake for 24 hours was pushing on my head and I felt like I might just collapse into a pile of dust.
If there was one thing I knew about sleep (or lack thereof) it was that you need to keep the times consistent. If I fell asleep now then it would mess up everything and I didn’t want that, especially just before our holiday.
I needed to do something. I turned around to face my bed but something was wrong. Something was missing. My heart skipped a beat as I realised and I turned and ran down the hall and into my brother’s room.
“Timmy!” I yelled at the top of my voice. “You stole it!“. He hadn’t even tried to hide it. On the floor, next to his bed was my Justin Bieber body pillow. I grabbed it by the feet and pulled it towards me.
Timmy didn’t look sorry at all. He just looked at me with one of those looks that makes adults’ anger melt instantly. I swung Justin by the feet and slammed it across his face. The force knocked him clean over and he sprawled onto the carpet. I bolted back to my room and slammed the door before his bawling echoed down the hallway. I heard the sound of my mum’s footsteps on the stairs and knew I was in trouble.
~
The bus doors opened and I waited for the large group ahead of us to get off. Timmy, being who he was, ducked and swerved though the crowd and rushed to the doors. The old lady he has just cut off grabbed onto the railing to save herself from falling. Mum seemed oblivious. Dad actually looked away. I cursed at them in my head and stared daggers at their shadows.
The wait was worth it though. The highlight of our holiday, the grand canyon. Something I had only seen on TV. It seemed bigger and deeper in real life.
Timmy, who had got off the bus long before all of us, was already by the canyon and was sitting on the fence. There was a strange gap in the people around him as if people were trying to disassociate themselves with this odd child. But that was not my thought I ran at him. The boy who had haunted my existence since the sad say of his birth, sitting on the edge of this colossal chasm, staring innocently down.

English/Sound-types.title: Sound types
English/Sound-types.content:
1. Manners of Articulation (Consonant Types)
These describe how the airflow is modified.
A. Obstruents (significant blockage)
Plosives / Stops
Airflow is completely blocked then released.
/p b t d k ɡ/
Affricates
Stop + fricative combination.
/tʃ dʒ/
Fricatives
Airflow is forced through a narrow constriction.
/f v θ ð s z ʃ ʒ h/
B. Sonorants (continuous, non-turbulent airflow)
Nasals
Air flows through the nose.
/m n ŋ/
Approximants
Airflow narrows but doesn’t create friction.


Glides: /j w/


Liquids:


Lateral: /l/


Rhotic: /ɹ/ (American-style “r”)





2. Places of Articulation (Where the tongue/lips constrict airflow)


Bilabial: /p b m w/


Labiodental: /f v/


Dental: /θ ð/


Alveolar: /t d s z n l ɹ/


Post-alveolar (palato-alveolar): /ʃ ʒ tʃ dʒ/


Palatal: /j/


Velar: /k ɡ ŋ/


Glottal: /h ʔ/ (the glottal stop appears in many accents, e.g. “bu’uh” for “butter”)



3. Voicing
Most English consonants come in voiced / voiceless pairs:


Voiceless: /p t k f θ s ʃ tʃ h/


Voiced: /b d ɡ v ð z ʒ dʒ m n ŋ l ɹ j w/



4. Vowel Categories
English vowel types can be grouped by tongue position, tenseness, and rounding.
Monophthongs (single, steady vowels)
Front: /i ɪ e ɛ æ/
Central: /ə ʌ ɝ ɚ/ (r-colored vowels in rhotic accents)
Back: /u ʊ o ɔ ɑ/
(Exact inventory differs by dialect.)
Diphthongs
Gliding vowels.
/aɪ aʊ ɔɪ eɪ oʊ/
Also r-colored diphthongs in rhotic dialects: /ɪɹ ɛɹ ʊɹ ɔɹ ɑɹ/

5. Suprasegmental Features (Prosody)
Not “sounds” but essential characteristics:


Stress (primary, secondary)


Intonation (pitch contour)


Rhythm


Syllable structure


Length / duration



6. Other Sound Categories
Glottal Stop
/ʔ/ occurs in many accents (e.g., “uh-oh”, or replacing /t/).
Flap / Tap
/ɾ/ (American “t/d” in “butter”, “ladder”).
Syllabic Consonants
/l̩ n̩/ where the consonant functions as a syllable nucleus (e.g. “bottle”, “button”).

Summary List (Quick Reference)
Consonant manners:


Plosive


Nasal


Fricative


Affricate


Approximant (glide, liquid)


Flap


Glottal stop


Vowel types:


Monophthongs


Diphthongs


R-colored vowels


(Optionally) Triphthongs (depending on dialect)


Suprasegmentals: stress, pitch, rhythm.

K_2CO_3 - Potassium carbonate
a solid salt formed during black-powder combustion.
Appears as part of the grey/white residue left after firing black powder.
During combustion, carbon from the charcoal partially oxidises but, because oxygen is limited, some reacts with potassium from the nitrate, forming this stable salt instead of more CO₂.
CO_2 - Carbon Dioxide
There is enough oxygen for all the carbon to oxidise
CO - Carbon Monoxide
The high temperature means that carbon monoxide form as well as CO2
N_2 - Nitrogen gas
Expands with the heat
Forms bc there is lots of nitrogen
K_2S - Potassium sulphide
Alkaline, corrosive
Why it forms is complex
Sulphur acts as a fuel and reacts readily with potassium.
During the burn, sulphur is first oxidised but then quickly reduced again due to the strongly reducing environment (lots of hot carbon and CO).
Potassium, which is extremely reactive towards sulphur, captures the reduced sulphur to form potassium sulphide.

_Climatology/2-Editors-Note.title: 2 Editors Note
_Climatology/2-Editors-Note.content:
Wind never stops. There was wind billions of years before there was life. The wind never gets tired, and most importantly: wind doesn’t release carbon-dioxide into the atmosphere.
Most of the energy sources that we rely on produce gases that are damaging to the climate or use resources that are limited and damaging to mine. But wind power harnesses a powerful natural force and uses it to produce electricity. This happens with no emissions, no mining and no toxic waste.
In this special edition of [name] we will look at the upsides and downsides of wind power, compare it to other power sources and speak with experts in the field. By the end of this edition you will be an expert in wind power, and you can decide whether you think that wind power is the best source of power.
Thank you for reading our magazine. Here’s a look at what’s to come:
[Table of contents]

_Climatology/3-Interview.title: 3 Interview
_Climatology/3-Interview.content:
My name is Patrick and I am the manager and director of Batsworthy Cross Wind Farm in Devon. We produce over 15 million kWh of electricity every year, enough to power roughly 8,700 households.
Can you tell us about the turbines?
We have nine turbines on the farm, each producing about 2 megawatts of power. They are all 103 metres tall and can spin at 60 rpm in good wind.
What is the lifespan of one of the turbines?
These kinds of turbine can last for 20-25 years with good maintenance.
Do the turbines interfere with the birds? Do birds get hit by the blades?
Yes, birds do often fly into the blades of the turbines but the amount of birds killed by wind turbines is fairly small, less than the bird deaths from cats or flying into buildings.
Do you believe that wind power is the future of eco-power?
I think that wind power is definitely a very good and eco-friendly power source but it can’t power the world alone. Other power sources like solar panels are also needed to keep up with the ever-increasing power demand.
What has improved in wind power in the last decade that the public wouldn’t know about?
There have been a lot of improvements to wind farms in the last decade. The main improvements that are constantly being made to turbines are increased hub height and bigger blades, allowing the turbines to catch more wind.
What improvements are still needing to be made?
Due to its simple nature, wind power isn’t advancing super fast. The main thing we need now is more wind farms. Wind power has come a long way but it’s still got a long way to go before it replaces all non-renewable energy.
What is something that everyone should know about wind power?
Wind power has the second least carbon emissions of any power source after nuclear power. Nuclear power has it’s own problems, so at least at the moment, wind power is our best source of energy. If we are going to stop climate change then we need to cut down drastically on carbon-dioxide emissions, and I believe that wind power is the way forward for power.


birds
noise
inland rather than offshore
cost and carbon footprint of making them
why do you do this?
lifespan
recycle
oil and carbons for maintenance
End with open question about moving industry forward

_Climatology/4-Main-Article.content:

Climate change

Core facts to draw a conclusion from


Are Wind Turbines the Future of Energy?
Electricity. We all rely on it, take it for granted, but often forget where it comes from and the side effects of its production. We use electricity every minute of every day but rarely stop and think. I want you to think back to yesterday. Every light you turned on, every time you charged your phone, every time you used your oven, all the electricity you used. Now think of every other person in the world, and all the offices, factories and shops. We use a lot of electricity every day. 75,000 gWh of electricity and rising fast.
But where does this electricity come from? Well this is where the problem lies. Only 44.9% of the UK’s energy comes from renewable sources. Climate change has become a huge issue and non-renewable energy is a massive part of it. Over 40% of carbon-dioxide emissions are from generating electricity.
We are, however, moving closer to green energy, but it’s not as perfect or simple as it might seem. In this article we are going to be discussing all the good and bad things about different types of green energy, specifically wind power.
Wind power turns the kinetic energy of the wind into electrical energy using turbines. The wind blows the blades of the turbine which turn a gearbox and then a generator. The most powerful wind turbine is a prototype from the Chinese company Dongfang Electric which has a power rating of 26MW. For comparison, an average UK house hold draws about 0.8kW of electricity.
Wind turbines come in two main variants: onshore and offshore. They are fundamentally the same but have a couple of key differences, the main one being that offshore turbines can be much bigger. Offshore wind farms can be huge, having well over 100 turbines.


                  
                  Pros 
                  
                


Low CO2
Lots of space in the sea for offshore wind farms
Cost effective - 1-2 cents per kWh
Space effective- the land can still be used for things like agriculture



The main advantage of wind power over other sources of energy is the low emissions. Wind power the emissions from wind energy are about 12g per kWh of electricity including the emissions from the production of the turbines and maintenance. The IPCC (1) has calculated a mean average of emissions for lots of power sources from a series of studies and wind power is listed as the source that emits the least carbon-dioxide.
Another major advantage of wind power is that it’s easily scalable. There is a lot of space in the sea for offshore wind farms. They are also highly cost effective. Offshore wind power can be produced for a little as $0.01 per kWh. This includes construction, operation and maintenance. Onshore wind is slightly cheaper to produce since they are just turbines and don’t need any surrounding structure.
They are also highly space efficient. The land around an onshore wind farm can still be used for something like agriculture as the turbines don’t take up a lot of ground space at their base.


                  
                  Cons 
                  
                


Ugly
Birds
Installation
Weather dependant



However, as with most things, its not all good. There are some major downsides to wind power but a lot of them only apply to onshore wind. A fairly common issue people have with wind turbines is that wind farms are ugly and they ruin landscapes. Of course this only applies to onshore wind but it can cause a huge barrier when getting planning permission.
I’ve already mentioned how wind farms don’t talk up a whole lot of ground space but that is only when they are running. Installation can be very disrupting to the surroundings due to the heavy machinery required.
Another thing that people often say about wind turbines is that they kill birds. While this is true, people are often unaware of the scale that this happens at. In the US, domestic cats are responsible for roughly one billion bird deaths every year while wind turbines only cause about 150,000. Turbines killing birds is not a huge issue and some manufacturers are now making their turbine blades black to reduce bird deaths even further.
But the main fundamental issue with wind power is that wind power is entirely weather dependant. If there is no wind, a turbine can’t make any power. This is a fundamental problem with the way that wind power works and there is no way to fix this. The only way around is storing the power.
Large scale power storage is already a thing, the largest is Dinorwig in North Wales. Seven billion litres of water are pumped 550 metres up a mountain and then flow back down through a generator when the power is needed. This method of power storage is currently the only thing we have at this scale but has a few core issues, the first being efficiency: it takes 3 units of power to pump the water up to the top and it will release 2 units of power on the way back down meaning that a third of the power is lost. Another downside is the money required to build it. Something like Dinorwig is very expensive to build, Dinorwig its self cost £425 million.
But the big question still has not been answered. Are wind turbines the future of energy? That is entirely down to you. After reading about all the advantages and all the problems, what do you think?

(1) - Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change

_Climatology/6-Speech.title: 6 Speech
_Climatology/6-Speech.content:
“How many times must a man look up before he can see the sky?”
That’s a quote from a famous song by Bob Dylan. I love that line because it reminds me that sometimes what we need is actually right there in front of us. I will argue that that is also the case with climate change.
We can actually replace some of the biggest sources of the problem, oil, coal and gas, with something we have in abundance: wind. In my country, Denmark, we are doing just that.
Nothing makes a Dane proud like the knowledge that something we have done makes a positive difference in the world. Historically speaking, we’ve made a difference before. 1,000 years ago, countrymen of mine controlled most of northern Europe. I’m sure you’ve heard of them: The Vikings.
Now I will make the case today that in order for us to fight climate change, we actually need to learn from the Vikings. But before we get to that, please indulge me. I have take you back in time. Not all the way back to the Viking age in the heydays of Harald “Bluetooth,” but to the 1970s during the oil crisis in Denmark. To a small workshop, in a barn, in a farm, in a village, in Denmark.
Meet Henrik Stiesdal.
He’s not an accomplished, experienced engineer. He’s 19 years old. He set himself a challenge. He thought, “What if I could make a wind turbine that could produce electricity?” And you know what? He did. And eventually he actually sold the design to a company called Vestas. You might have heard of them because they are the biggest turbine producer in the world today. So the story of wind power in Denmark is the story about how one turbine, on one farm sparked a transformation that influenced the whole country.
We are a green frontrunner, but we need to do more because at the same time, we rank as one of the biggest oil producers in the EU. This has to change. And it will. We’ve decided to put an end date on extraction of oil and gas in 2050 and immediately cancel all future licensing rounds. That wasn’t an easy decision. But the reason we made it, even though it was expensive, was because we need to show the world that there are actually alternatives to oil and gas.
Now, some of you are probably thinking that sounds very good, but how will you do it? Surely you cannot fly a jet plane without jet fuels? Surely you cannot sail a big container ship without bunker oil?
But actually, you can. This is an electrolyzer. It transforms electricity into hydrogen. And that, friends, that’s the game changer. Because the hydrogen can be transformed into green fuels. The wind in the North Sea is transformed by a turbine into electricity. The electrolyzer transforms that into hydrogen, and the hydrogen is then made into green, sustainable fuels that we can use to sail our ships and fly our planes. I know it sounds like science fiction, but actually it’s just science.
Some of you are probably thinking, “What does this have to do with the Vikings?” Do you know what it was that made the Vikings so successful? Their secret? They exploited the wind. And that brings me to my main point. We need, as the Vikings did 1,000 years ago, to change the world by finding new and more efficient ways of exploiting the energy.
Now, some people will probably tell you that a small country cannot make a big difference. I beg to differ. When a young man like Henrik could make a difference for a whole country, why not also believe that a country like Denmark can make a difference for a whole world? If you ask the International Energy Agency, they will tell you that offshore wind has the potential to cover the current electricity demand of the entire world, not once, not twice, 18 times.
So when you go to Denmark, you’ll meet a Dane. Try and ask them, “How do you think we should solve the climate crisis?” Chances are, they will say, “The answer, my friend, is literally blowing in the wind.”
Thank you.

_History/Book-Work/1-Early-Human-Evoluti.title: 1 Early Human Evolution
_History/Book-Work/1-Early-Human-Evoluti.content:
Imagine back to millions of years ago. The first organisms are just starting to form and they all live in the water. How did we come from this to humans? When thinking about evolution, your first thought might be chimpanzees. Everyone knows that humans are closely related (compared to other creatures) to chimpanzees. But chimpanzees aren’t our closest relatives. They are only the closest still alive.
Hominins were an early human-like species group. The first known hominin lived about 7 million years ago in central Africa. There were many species, and they gradually evolved towards Homo Sapiens (humans).
As the hominins continued to evolve, advances like cooking of food and making stone tools meant faster brain development and safer living, helping these species become more dominant than the ones without.
About 2 million years ago, Homo Erectus were the first hominin to migrate out of Africa. They were very similar to Homo Sapiens and had a brain far larger than any of the other Hominins. About 200,000 years ago, Homo Sapiens emerged. They quickly spread, and some think they are (at least partly) responsible for the extinction of Homo Erectus.

_History/Book-Work/10-I-am-poem.title: 10 I am poem
_History/Book-Work/10-I-am-poem.content:
I am the first life, the forming of the cells, the first heart beat.
I am the first human walking on two legs.
I am the spark of fire that lit up the night.
I am the first footstep outside of African soil.
I am the Lowenmensch passed around the fire.
I am the chanting of the tribes, echoing into the night.
I am a carved stone pillar, casting my shadow onto the long grass.
I am the sprouting seed that will grow into golden wheat.
I am a mud brick hut, housing a family.
I am the first scholar, printing symbols with my reed.
I am a judge, deciding the fate of the wrongdoers.
I am the invading force, the fall of the empires.
I am the hurricanes, the earthquakes, the falling rubble, the flames.
I am the echoes of the past life.
Whispering into the new.

_History/Book-Work/2-Lowenmensch.title: 2 Lowenmensch
_History/Book-Work/2-Lowenmensch.content:
The Lowenmensch (German for “Lion Man”) is a small sculpture made from a mammoth tusk. It is 31cm tall and depicts a man with a lion head standing up tall. It was made about 40,000 years ago in the Upper Palaeolithic period. It has no purpose or use other than to just be nice, and so is one of the earlies pieces of art.
When it was discovered in the Lone Valley in Germany in 1939, it was in pieces and had to be reconstructed by specialists. Excavation began again after the war and continued until 2012-13 when most of the pieces had been found. It has been studied and analysed a lot since then.
Signs of wear around its middle suggest that it has been handled a lot, not just left and looked at, and it was probably used for some kind of ceremony or ritual. It is one of the oldest representations of a being that does not exist in nature.
A few years ago artist Wulf Hein recreated the Lowenmensch using the same tools and techniques that would have been used to create the original and it took him over 400 hours. The original sculptor would not have been able to hunt or gather during the carving so would have been supported by his community, meaning the Lowenmensch must have had some special value to the group.


                  
                  A real artist made this. He was set free by his community only to do this piece of artwork. – Wulf Hein

_History/Book-Work/3-Gobekli-Tepe.title: 3 Gobekli Tepe
_History/Book-Work/3-Gobekli-Tepe.content:
In 1994, archaeologist Klaus Scmidt made a discovery of a lifetime in south-eastern Turkey. An 11,000 (Neolithic period) year old construction made up of beautifully decorated t-shaped limestone pillars. Each pillar is about 5m high and intricately carved with patterns, flowers, plants and animals. They weigh up to 10 tons and are angled towards Sirius, the brightest star in the sky.
However, the odd thing about Göbekli Tepe: no other settlements have been discovered near by. This suggests that Göbekli Tepe was a joint effort of lots of groups. But how did they all meet at this place? Why here? Sadly there is probably no way to answer these questions, we can only guess. The most likely use of the site was rituals. Lots of tribes would have come to the site for a ceremony. There are no signs that anyone lived there.
The complexity of Göbekli Tepe shows that the people of this time were able to plan, design and construct very complex things, even with the very simple tools they had. Only a small amount of the site has been excavated but surveys have shown that there is more to the structure that is still buried.
Göbekli Tepe is listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is one of the earliest examples of human architecture. It is a key to the understanding of prehistoric people due to its size and level of preservation.

_History/Book-Work/4-Agricultural-Revolu.title: 4 Agricultural Revolution
_History/Book-Work/4-Agricultural-Revolu.content:
The agricultural revolution started around 10,000 BC—roughly at the end of the last Ice Age—in the fertile crescent (now known as the Middle East) when the people started farming. It started with the harvesting of naturally growing wheat. The people discovered how to turn it into flour, dough and flatbread. But the process was slow. Extracting the grains from the wheat ears was a difficult and time consuming process. Many kinds of tools where invented to help the process.
Having more available food meant the population grew and the population growing meant more demand for food. The people started to plant grains closer to home, creating fields of crops. Now instead of hunter-gatherers, who were always moving, the people settled in one place and built more permanent homes and villages.
Towns grew around the agriculture, forming fewer larger groups; the people started to keep cows and sheep, meaning better clothes and easy meat. But some groups were doing better than others; they had more wheat, healthier cows, better wool. The towns with less started to envy the towns with more and they started to steal. Towns built defences against intruders and appointed leaders and defenders.
The agricultural revolution brought many positive things to society: permanent settlements, more stable food supply, trading and advances in technology and tools. But it wasn’t all good. With people and animals living together, diseases started to spread like smallpox and measles. People separated into groups and fought over land and possessions.
But whether it was good or bad, the agricultural revolution was a huge turning point in human development and brought us closer to where we are today.

_History/Book-Work/5-Catal-Hoyuk.title: 5 Catal Hoyuk
_History/Book-Work/5-Catal-Hoyuk.content:
Çatal Höyuk is an ancient settlement found in southern Turkey. It is the earliest known Neolithic settlement, and covers over 12 hectares. It was inhabited between c. 7100 BCE and c. 6000 BCE and is estimated to have had 5000—8000 inhabitants at its peak. It was discovered by James Mellaart in 1958 and excavated throughout the 1960s and 1990s. In 2012 Çatal Höyuk became a World Heritage Site.
Çatal Höyuk was very different to cities and towns today. There were no streets or roads, the people walked on the roofs. The only entrance to the houses was down a ladder through a hole in the roof. The hole also acted as a chimney. The cooking was done on the second floor under the hole. They slept on the bottom floor, all on a raised platform surrounded by mammoth tusks. The exact reason for the mammoth tusks is unknown but it is thought to be for spiritual protection. The houses were built from mudbrick and wood and all the houses were more or less the same. This indicates that there was no social hierarchy.
The dead were buried underneath the sleeping platform in pits which were then covered. The bodies were bound tightly in the foetal position to fit in the holes. The holes would be periodically reopened to for bodies to be added. The houses were decorated with wall paintings and sculptures, a lot of them suggesting some spiritual belief. Archaeologists believe that the town did not have a sudden collapse, instead people gradually moved away until the town was eventually abandoned.

_History/Book-Work/6-Uruk.title: 6 Uruk
_History/Book-Work/6-Uruk.content:
Uruk is an ancient city located in southern Mesopotamia, what is now Iraq. Many scholars consider it to be the first true city. Its even mentioned in the bible (referred to as Erech). Between 3500 and 3000 BCE, Uruk dominated Mesopotamia and is so influential that it gave its name to a whole archaeological period: the Uruk Period.
At its peak, Uruk had a population of around 40,000 people (about the same as Salisbury) which was huge for the times. It it between two rivers, the Tigris and the Euphrates and had lots of canals connected to the rivers. The canals were used for transport around the city.
Uruk contained large ziggurats (temples for public worship) including the Anu ziggurat, one of the best preserved structures in the city. The houses were made from mud bricks and were built around the canals.
The very first writing, small pictograms in clay, was found in Uruk, c. 3200 BCE. This is what later evolved into cuneiform writing, the first established form of writing.
The legendary king Gilgamesh is thought to have ruled Uruk around 2700 BCE. He is said to have built the city wall and he is the protagonist of the oldest known epic poem, the Epic of Gilgamesh which is written in cuneiform on clay tablets.
Uruk was invaded, destroyed and rebuilt many times until c. 300 CE when it was gradually abandoned due to a shift in the Euphrates river.
Today Uruk is a important archaeological site for understanding the people and society of the time and marks a key point in human development due to its size.

_History/Book-Work/8-Hammurabi.title: 8 Hammurabi
_History/Book-Work/8-Hammurabi.content:
Hammurabi was the King of Babylon from 1792 to 1750 BCE. During his reign he created the Code of Hammurabi, one of the earliest and most complete legal codes. It was written in cuneiform on a basalt stele that was over two metres tall. It was first erected in Babylon in the temple of Marduk but is thought to have later been stolen as it was found in the ancient city of Susa, Persia (now Iran).
Written on the stele was not only the laws but a prologue and epilogue about the greatness of King Hammurabi. There were 282 laws in total and they spanned many areas of law: family, property, trade, employment, crime and civil law. All the laws listed a crime and a punishment for that crime but the punishment differed by social class, for example, slaves were considered property and had limited legal rights.

If any one strike the body of a man higher in rank than he, he shall receive sixty blows with an ox-whip in public.

Some of the laws were not particularly fair and often the accuser would be punished if they could not prove guilt. For example: If any one bring an accusation of any crime before the elders, and does not prove what he has charged, he shall, if it be a capital offence charged, be put to death.
A lot of the listed crimes were punished by death and lots were on the basis of suffering what you did to another:
If a man knock out the teeth of his equal, his teeth shall be knocked out.
If a man put out the eye of another man, his eye shall be put out.
If he break another man’s bone, his bone shall be broken.
The code also talks about rates of pay for different jobs and products.
If any one hire a field laborer, he shall pay him eight gur of corn per year.
If any one hire an ox-driver, he shall pay him six gur of corn per year.
Although these laws seem harsh they were a significant improvement on previous Assyrian law which involved whipping and dismembering of body parts.
The stele is now in the Louvre in Paris.

_History/Book-Work/9-Bronze-Age-Collapse.title: 9 Bronze Age Collapse
_History/Book-Work/9-Bronze-Age-Collapse.content:
The term Bronze Age Collapse refers to the fall of settlements in Mesopotamia and around the Mediterranean. It happened around c. 1250 - c. 1150 BCE but the exact cause is disagreed on by historians.
The leading theory of the cause of the collapse is an invasion of a group now known as the Sea Peoples. Egyptian texts describe an invasion and archaeologists have found evidence of cities being burned down.
Another theory is natural disasters. There is evidence of big earthquakes happening around this time which would have collapsed city walls and houses, making the cities uninhabitable and leaving the people homeless and in danger.
There is also evidence of climate change and drought in fossilised pollen. This would have caused crops to fail, livestock to die and so a widespread famine. Another theory is an uprising of peasants which could have been caused by the famine.
Any of these things could have caused the rapid failing of the civilisation. As with a lot of history, there is no way to say for certain what actually happened but these are some very likely theories backed by archaeological evidence.
But just for a second, imagine this: a world with a rapidly changing climate and destabilising society, the wealthy have grown too wealthy and the poor are too poor. Society is splitting and the poorer people are getting fed up. Do you actually have to imagine…?

_History/W3-D3.title: W3-D3
_History/W3-D3.content:
The most important thing in human history has got to be the start of proper language. How could we have got anywhere without being able to talk to each other? Look the animal kingdom. Any species that does more than wander around and eat leaves has some form of communication. Birds have special calls for danger, bees use body language to tell the hive where the flowers are and even antisocial animals like cats have a way of expressing their dislike of each other.
Imagine trying to build a pyramid but you have no way of communicating with anyone else, not even pointing or waving. Now imagine you can point, it’s not much but the construction might now be possible. Now imagine it with very crude language. You can now do things like asking for help or requesting more stone to be fetched. Its getting easier but would still take a long time and a lot of mishaps. Now imagine it with a fully formed language. Someone can now take charge and direct the construction. People can be assigned jobs, progress can be reported and the whole thing would be so much easier.
Now add writing to the mix. Records can now be kept without worry of forgetting or slight changes when information is passed by word of mouth. Large lists can be made, letters can be sent. Humans are the only animals with a way of recording information in symbols and it has changed the way we live so dramatically.
Lets go back to the pyramid and add writing to the mix. Records of progress can now be written, designs can be made and lists of materials can be sent to where they need to go. This changes everything again and speeds up construction even more.
But none of this would have come around if it wasn’t for fire. The harnessing of fire changed everything in so many ways. The ability to cook food, meaning faster brain development; a controllable light source, in fact the only light source besides the sun; and a bringer of safety and warmth at night. All of this meant that the people had more time and could do things other than keeping themselves alive. They started to tell stories, make art, sing songs and have some sense of community. This might be the most important landmarks in human development due to the volume of things that wouldn’t have happened without it.
The power of humans has always been their ability to work together for the benefit of the group, to be selfless and to consider others needs as well as their own. Our sense of community, empathy and love for each other.

Phaeacia Farage — 1st Oct
Princess attacked by crusty immigrant old man
Earlier this morning, our own princess Nausicaa was spotted coming out of the woods with a fully naked man. The man seemed to be speaking to the princess with strong emotion and was thought to be seducing her. After sending the handmaidens away, the man oiled up by the river while Nausicaa watched. He then lead her off into the woods, still naked.
The two have not been seen since the incident. Reporters suspect a sexual scandal but if they are not seen in the next few days then they may have eloped. The king and queen have also not been sighted but we suspect they are oblivious to their daughter’s situation.
Interviews with residents reveal that the man is not from our island and could potentially be dangerous. We suggest keeping valuables close and not carrying a large amount of money.

_Odyssey/Class-notes/W3-D2.content: Odysseus told the crew not to kill the cows and sheep but didn’t actually tell them why they shouldn’t so when they ran out of food, the crew saw the cows as easy prey and not as the potential danger that they were. _Odyssey/Class-notes/W4-D1.title: W4-D1
_Odyssey/Class-notes/W4-D1.content:
Concept of a hero


                  
                  HERO - noun 
                  
                

a person who is admired for their courage, outstanding achievements, or noble qualities.
Oxford Languages


Nowadays, Odysseus would not be hailed as a hero and warrior but would probably be considered a terrorist. However the expectations of people these days is very different to Ancient Greece. In modern colloquial language, the word “Hero” gets used quite often so the definition has become quite loose.
The archetypal hero is the prince rescuing a princess from a tower but it seems more complex than that. Odysseus, Prince Charming, David Attenborough, Donald Trump, Lebron James; they are all considered heros to some people but disliked (some more than others) by another group.

_Odyssey/Class-notes/W4-D3.title: W4-D3
_Odyssey/Class-notes/W4-D3.content:
When Odysseus returned to Ithaca, having a load of men in his house harassing his wife was probably not the welcome home he was hoping for. His anger and frustration is completely understandable but maybe there was a better way to deal with it.
If Odysseus had instead hidden all the weapons and then announced himself to the suitors, bloodshed could have potentially been avoided. Of course if the suitors had reacted by attacking Odysseus or Telemachus then killing them is much more justifiable.
Straight up murder is always hard to justify and this is not really any different. The harassment of his wife and son is bad but I still don’t think it justifies homicide.

_Odyssey/Class-notes/W4-D4.title: W4-D4
_Odyssey/Class-notes/W4-D4.content: Athena has got to be the best character. I love her mysteriousness, craftiness and genius and the way that she is a massive part of the story without being in it a lot. Without Athena, Odysseus would have died very early on. I also like how she is helping Odysseus but hiding it from Poseidon. The implied “war” among the gods adds to the story and makes Athena such a deep character.

_Odyssey/Top-Trumps.title: Top Trumps
_Odyssey/Top-Trumps.content:
Stats

Strength
Skill
Cunning
Luck
Morals
Plot Armor

Characters

Homer
Homer is the poet behind the Odyssey and the Iliad, and is one of the most important Ancient Greek poets to ever live. Some people question whether he was actually a single person or a name for a group of poets.
Odysseus
Odysseus is the main character in the Odyssey and is a strong and skilled fighter. His leadership is sometimes questionable, but he will always triumph in combat. Although it often seems otherwise, he is very loyal to his wife Penelope and is desperate to get back to her.
Athena
Athena is the god of wisdom, war and handicraft. She goes against her brother Poseidon and helps Odysseus to return home. As the most prominent god in the story, she is the link between the storyline of the journey of Odysseus and the storyline of the tension up on Olympus.
Penelope
Penelope is the long suffering wife of Odysseus. During his twenty-year absence, she is being courted by 106 suitors and longing for the return of her husband. When he eventually returns and kills all the suitors, their love is very prominently shown.
Telemachus
Telemachus is the son of Odysseus and protector of his mother. He is the one who holds the suitors off her and keeps her safe. Even though he has never really known his father, when Odysseus returns, the two plan and execute the demise of the suitors.
Poseidon
Poseidon is the god of the sea and dislikes Odysseus for blinding his son, Polyphemus. Several of Odysseus’s misfortunes are sent from Poseidon. Since Odysseus is sailing home he is in Poseidon’s domain and at his mercy.
Zeus
Zeus is the king of Olympus and god of the sky. Even though he would like Odysseus to return home, he doesn’t interfere until he destroys the ship with a thunderbolt at the command of Helios.
Hermes
Hermes is the messenger of the gods and is the one to deliver the message to Calypso that she is to release Odysseus. He also helps Odysseus avoid Circe’s magic when she turns Odysseus’s crew into swine.
Calypso
Calypso is the nymph who held Odysseus on her island for seven years after his ship was destroyed by Zeus. Despite being deeply in love with him and promising him immortality if he stays, she does not object to letting him go when instructed to by the Olympians.
Circe
Circe is a cunning enchantress and Odysseus’s first affair is with her. When Odysseus outsmarts her she falls in love and lets him stay on her island for a year, longer than would have been seen as appropriate of the hospitality rules at the time. When he eventually leaves, she gives him advice to continue his journey.
Helios
Helios is the god of the sun, and it is his cows that Odysseus’s crew unknowingly kill. In rage, Helios has Zeus strike the ship, and all the crew are killed by the whirlpool, Charybdis. Helios is responsible for fulfilling the last bit of the prophesy: that Odysseus will return alone.
Helios’s Cows
Helios’s cows are no ordinary cows. They are the cows of the sun god. They produce golden milk and the tastiest steak you have ever tasted. Oh, you tasted their steak? Too bad, you angered a god. You will now be struck by Zeus and killed. (not 100% accurate)
Polyphemus
Polyphemus is the one-eyed son of Poseidon and lives peacefully on an island with other Cyclopes. He tends lovingly to his sheep, but when Odysseus arrives, his vicious side comes out. After blinding Polyphemus, Odysseus escapes and shouts abuse back at the Cyclops. Polyphemus curses Odysseus, dooming him to suffer the ten year journey home.
Eumaeus
Eumaeus is a swineherd and loyal to his master, Odysseus. He keeps his pigs up on the hill and will take you in and cook you a pork chop if you turn up on his doorstep. When Odysseus returns to Ithaca, he stays with Eumaeus until he has rid his house of the suitors.
Eurycleia
Eurycleia is a loyal maid of Odysseus and Penelope. When Odysseus turns up as a beggar, she washes his feet and spots a scar that she recognises. When she tries to tell Penelope, she is quickly silenced by Odysseus and has to hold the secret until the suitors have gone.
Antinous
Antinous is the leader of the suitors and the first suitor to die at the hand of Odysseus. He is the most abusive to Penelope and the most horrible to the maids. When Odysseus comes to the palace, Antinous throws a stool at him for a cheap laugh.
Eurymachus
Eurymachus is one of the suitors, and it is him who plots to kill Telemachus. He is very manipulative and even tricks Penelope into thinking he is a good man. After Odysseus shoots Antinous, Eurymachus pleads to Odysseus, saying it is all Antinous, but Odysseus sees right through his lies.
Laertes
Laertes is the father of Odysseus and is heartbroken when he doesn’t return after the war with the rest of the army. After all the suitors are killed, Odysseus is reunited with his father who is overjoyed.
Nausicaa
Nausicaa is the princess of Phaeacia and when Odysseus washes up on the beach in Phaeacia, Athena sends Nausicaa a dream telling her to go to wash her clothes. When Odysseus wakes up, he sees Nausicaa washing her clothes, and she takes him to the king.
Alcinous
Alcinous is the king of Phaeacia and is the one to finally take Odysseus home. He gives Odysseus so many gifts that he has to raise the taxes and also offers his daughter, Nausicaa, as a wife, although Odysseus declines.
Aeolus
Aeolus is the god of the winds and lives with his wife, six daughters and six sons on the floating island of Aeolia. Each of his six sons are married to one of his six daughters, and not many people visit the island. When Odysseus asks Aeolus for help, Aeolus puts all but the west wind in a bag.
Elpenor
Elpenor is a member of Odysseus’s crew and he likes to drink. When the crew are leaving Circe’s island, Elpenor falls from the roof and dies. Since the crew are in a hurry, they don’t give Elpenor a funeral, but when they meet him in the land of the dead, he instructs them to return and do so.
Tiresias
Tiresias is a prophet whom Odysseus speaks with in the land of the dead. He tells Odysseus about the next part of his journey. He warns Odysseus about the cows of the sun god Helios and instructs him not to harm them.
The Sirens
The Sirens are creatures of the sea, and they lure in mortals with their song and eat them alive. When Odysseus and his crew sail past, all the crew block their ears with wax, but Odysseus is tied to the mast and keeps his ears unblocked.
Agamemnon
Agamemnon is the husband of Helen and lives in Sparta. Telemachus goes to visit at the instruction of King Nestor when he is searching for his father. Agamemnon is still scared from the Trojan war and struggles with normal life after ten years of fighting.
Helen
Helen is the wife of Agamemnon and the cause of the Trojan war. She keeps her husband sane and calm by putting sleeping drugs in his wine. Since the Trojan war she appears to have changed and just wants a peaceful, normal life with Agamemnon.
Pisistratus
Pisistratus is the son of King Nestor and becomes a good friend to Telemachus, whom he helps in his search for Odysseus. The two go to Sparta to visit Agamemnon in the chariot belonging to Pisistratus and become good friends.
The Lotus-Eaters
The Lotus-Eaters are just a group of happy addicts on a small island who spend all day eating the Lotus and getting high. It’s a simple life, but not a bad one. There is no conflict, no poverty, no arguing, just Lotus.

_Physics/Book/3-Azimuth.title: 3 Azimuth
_Physics/Book/3-Azimuth.content: Azimuth is a way of describing a direction in a mathematical way. It uses a number between 0 and 360. It can be used in conjunction with a direction to describe a translation or with a speed to describe movement.

_Physics/Book/Free-Fall-Experiment.title: Free Fall Experiment
_Physics/Book/Free-Fall-Experiment.content:
Equipment

Tennis ball
Juggling ball
Stone
Stop watch
Balcony

Method
The tennis ball, juggling ball and rock were all dropped off the balcony one by one and the drop times were measured with the stopwatch and recorded. Three measurements were taken for each.
Data



































TennisJugglingStoneDrop 11.161.141.71Drop 21.280.860.78Drop 31.130.901.46Avg1.190.971.32
Observations
The fall times are within the range of human error. All the items fell in close enough to the same time that measuring the difference is not possible without special equipment.
Conclusion
The mass of an object does not effect fall time.

_Physics/Book/Golf-Ball-Bouncing-Experim.title: Golf Ball Bouncing Experiment
_Physics/Book/Golf-Ball-Bouncing-Experim.content:
Equipment

Golf ball
Hard floor

Method
The golf ball was lifted above the floor and dropped. It was allowed to bounce five times before it was stopped. The process was then repeated with more bounces.
Observations
As the ball bounced on the floor, it lost height and the bounces became more frequent. When dropping from \approx 2m, the ball bounced \approx 20 \space times before coming to rest on the floor.
Conclusion
When dropped, a ball looses velocity rapidly when bouncing on a floor.

_Physics/Book/Levers.title: Levers
_Physics/Book/Levers.content:
Introduction
Levers are one of the six basic machines and a fundamental part of nearly all machinery. They do the simple task of changing high power, small distance into low power, large distance or vice versa. There are three types (or classes) of lever, determined by the order of the components: load, effort and fulcrum.
A first class lever is your typical lever. It has the fulcrum in the middle and the load and effort either side. The conversion of the force depends on the distances between the fulcrum and effort, and the fulcrum and load. This type of lever is the main component in scales and see-saws.
A second class lever has the load in the middle and the fulcrum and effort at the ends. It turns a low power, high distance effort into a high power, low distance force. This type of lever is useful for lifting heavy things and exerting a large amount of force onto something. Nut crackers are made of a pair of second class levers.
Third class levers have the effort in the middle and turn high power, low distance into high distance, low power. Chop sticks, tweezers, clap boards and even elbows are third class levers.
Levers are a key part of so many machines and have been used for thousands of years. They were used in the construction of the pyramids and are a key part of steam engines. Think about any piece of moving machinery. How many levers are there in it? There is almost certainly at least one and probably more. Even though levers have been used for thousands of years, the mathematics of levers wasn’t done until Greek times and is credited to Archimedes and his Law of Levers.
Balance Experiment
Equipment

First class lever with evenly spread hooks
Set of equal weights

Method
The lever setup was checked to make sure it was balanced with no weights and then different combinations of weights were added on each side to find what balanced.
Observations
The lever was balanced when two weights were put on opposite sides in the same place. When they were different distances from the fulcrum, the side with the weight further out went down. When a pair of weights was on one side and only one weight on the other, the pair of weights needed to be half as far out as the single weight for the lever to balance. If one of the pair of weights was moved inwards and one outwards, the lever would stay balanced.
Conclusion
Weights on a scale or first class lever are more “effective” the further out they are from the fulcrum; the amount of influence that a weight has on the balance increases in a linear fashion as it is moved further from the fulcrum.

_Physics/Why-Alin's-calculations-are-wro.title: Why Alin's calculations are wrong - scientific research paper
_Physics/Why-Alin's-calculations-are-wro.content:
1. Introduction
The tennis ball dropping experiment was conducted by dropping a tennis ball from a balcony.
Alin has made a calculation for the fall time of the tennis ball from the balcony. His result is 0.5 - 0.7 seconds. I am going to prove this wrong.
2. Numbers
In this document, the following variables will be used:
r - radius of the ball = 0.033m
H - start height of the fall = 4.38m
c - drag coefficient of the ball = 0.53
g - gravity = 9.8
w - weight of the ball = 0.0572kg
\rho - air density = 1.004 (real air density at 7th November 2025 at 9:00)
Note on units: Meters, seconds and kilograms will be used throughout
3. Calculations
Now I will calculate the fall time for the tennis ball using the above numbers, first without air resistance, and then with.
3.1 Without Air Resistance
The formula for fall time without air is:
t=\sqrt{2H \over g}
Plugging in the values we get:
t=\sqrt{2 \times 4.38 \over 9.8}
Solve for t:
t=\sqrt{2 \times 4.38 \over 9.8} = \sqrt{8.78 \over 9.8} \approx \sqrt{0.894} \approx \boldsymbol{0.946}
So without air, the fall time would be \approx 0.946
3.2 With Air Resistance
To calculate the distance that a body has fallen after a given amount of time, we can use this formula:
f\left(t\right)=\frac{2m}{\rho cA}\ln\left(\left[\cosh\left(t\sqrt{\frac{g\rho cA}{2m}}\right)\right]\right)
This formula uses calculus to calculate the distance an object has fallen after a given amount of time.
If we plot this together with y=4.38 for the distance we find that they intersect at y=0.98993 so that is the fall time, with air resistance, for the tennis ball.
4. Conclusion
The fall time for the tennis ball in a vacuum would be roughly 0.946 seconds.
The fall time with air resistance should be roughly 0.99 seconds.


                  
                  Note on buoyancy 
                  
                

Buoyancy calculations have not been done here. This is because the difference that it makes to the final number is within the error margin of the calculations and would therefor be fairly pointless.

_Poetry/Haiku-History.title: Haiku History
_Poetry/Haiku-History.content:
The haiku is a very short form of poetry that comes from Japan. A haiku is made up of just three lines and usually focuses on nature or a small moment in time. Because of its simplicity, the haiku encourages the reader to slow down and think carefully about what is being described.
Haikus originated in Japan several hundred years ago. It developed from an older form of poetry called renga. The opening verse of a renga was called a hokku, and over time this opening verse became more important on its own. Eventually, the hokku became what we now call the haiku.
A haiku follows a syllable pattern of 5 syllables in the first line, 7 in the second, and 5 in the third. Haikus usually include a reference to nature or the seasons, known as a kigo, and contain a pause or break in thought called a kireji, which adds meaning or contrast. The kireji comes from a Japanese-English language difference in how punctuation works.
The most famous haiku poet is Matsuo Bashō, who lived in the 17th century. Bashō helped turn haiku into a respected form of poetry. His haikus often described nature, travel, and everyday moments, such as the sound of water.
Haiku later spread beyond Japan to other parts of the world and poets began writing haikus in their own languages. Because different languages work differently, many writers outside Japan focused less on strict syllable counts and more on the overall feeling of the poem. English haikus often keep the three-line structure but don’t always follow the 5-7-5 pattern exactly.
Haikus are still very popular. Modern haikus can be about almost anything, not just nature. Some poets write about emotions, daily life, or modern technology. Even though the subject matter has changed, the main idea of capturing a brief moment remains the same.

_Poetry/Haiku.title: Haiku
_Poetry/Haiku.content:
The parting of clouds
A beam of sun shining down
Then the beam is gone
The chill of the air
The echo of my breathing
Through the mossy headstones
Dark rain clouds above
The icy cold wind blowing
Winter is still here
The darkness of night
The patter of night time rain
A storm is coming
The grass in the wind
The sway of the tall flowers
The swing of branches

_Poetry/Poetry-and-Me.title: Poetry and Me
_Poetry/Poetry-and-Me.content:
I’ve always enjoyed poetry. From fairly young I was read poems by my parents and grandparents and then read them by myself when I could read. I always enjoyed picture books with rhymes and tongue twisters, especially Dr Seuss; and nonsense poems like those of Spike Milligan, Edward Lear and Michael Rosen. I remember reading the Dr Seuss books and struggling to say all the words.
My favourite has got to be Fox in Socks and I can still say several parts of it from memory. I also remember several Spike Milligan poems like The Ning Nang Nong (featuring later in this book) and Bongaloo. Now that I am older I enjoy slightly different poetry but still of a similar style like Brian Bilston. His poetry is very funny and different but not entirely meaningless or complete nonsense. He writes about very real and current subjects but keeps it approachable and light. A couple of my favourites by him are How much I dislike the Daily Mail, Mnemonic and his many hilarious haikus.
I don’t particularly like long, drawn out and unrhythmic poems. I was forced to sit through lots of these poems during lockdown when my grandpa would read them to me, my sister and our cousins over Zoom. I think this might have been what put me off serious poetry but I have more recently enjoyed some more serious poems like Dulce et Decorum Est by Wilfred Owen.
The thing I love about poetry is the rhythms. As a very musical person, complex rhythms and beats feel very satisfying to me. Poems with strong repeating rhythms stick in my head. I also like the deeper meanings behind poems. How you have to draw your own conclusions and uncover hidden meanings by thinking about it from a different angle. You could see something that the poet didn’t intend to say but that speaks to you, and that’s the magic of poetry, and why I think that dissecting and analysing poems is spoiling them. It loses the magic, forces you to see it from a certain angle.
I think that poems are a very special art form and form of expression. It carries a deep meaning or message, like music, but it’s not always obvious, like art. It is a very special form of writing that comes in so many forms and everyone can enjoy it if they find the right flavour.

_Poetry/Sestina-History.title: Sestina History
_Poetry/Sestina-History.content:
The sestina is a type of poem that is known for being very challenging to write. It is not as common as the sonnet, but it is still an important poetic form. It repeats the same six words at the ends of lines in a specific pattern. It doesn’t follow a meter or have a set line length.
The sestina originated in the twelfth century in France and was created by a poet named Arnaut Daniel. Daniel was known for writing complicated poems, and the sestina is one of his most famous inventions. At the time, poetry was often performed out loud, and the repeated words helped listeners follow the poem more easily.
A sestina is made up of six stanzas, each with six lines, followed by a final three-line stanza called an envoi. The same six words are used at the end of every line, but they appear in a different order each time. This order is very strict and follows a set pattern. In the envoi, all six words appear again, two per line. Because the poet cannot change the end words, writing a sestina requires very careful planning and choosing of the words.
When the sestina spread to Italy during the Middle Ages, and then to the rest of Europe during the Renaissance. Some poets avoided it because it was difficult to write and very restrictive. However, others enjoyed the challenge and used the repetition to help the tone of the poem.
Poets still write sestinas today, although not as much. Writers such as Elizabeth Bishop have written sestinas about emotional subjects, just like they would have been originally.

_Poetry/Sestina-Print.title: Sestina Print
_Poetry/Sestina-Print.content:
Sat at the bottom because of the other.
Staring off through the mist into the distance.
These infinite impenetrable spaces unending,
A liminal world, unimaginable depth.
The unknown beyond, don’t peek behind the veil,
The echoing emptiness may not be empty.
The echoing chambers not quite empty,
This is the doing of the other.
This is not safe, don’t peek behind the veil;
You don’t know what’s in the distance.
You are not safe down in the depth,
Your suffering will come to an ending.
Don’t let the darkness be unending,
Don’t let the emptiness be empty.
Don’t let the liminal space’s depth,
Stretch more than the depth of the heart of the other.
Pull back the deep dark infinite distance
Take a look behind the veil
But in the darkness behind the veil
I feel suffering and no ending.
Stay away, keep your distance
The echoing emptiness is not empty.
Stay away, don’t challenge the other
Don’t fall down into the depth.
But I must fall into the depth,
Push aside the veil
And challenge the other,
This is the only way to an ending.
Make the emptiness not empty,
See what’s in the distance.
Now you have travelled this distance,
Fell down to this depth,
Seen that the emptiness is not empty,
Pushed aside the veil,
And reached for this ending.
In spite of the other.

The distance behind the veil,
The depth of the ending,
The emptiness of the other.

_Poetry/Sonnet-History.title: Sonnet History
_Poetry/Sonnet-History.content:
The sonnet is one of the oldest types of poem and they have been around for hundreds of years. They originated in Sicily in the thirteenth century. It is commonly believed that a poet named Giacomo da Lentini invented the sonnet. Early sonnets followed the rhyme scheme ABABABAB CDCDCD but this later changed. These poems were written in Italian and were mainly used to explore emotions, especially love.
From Sicily, the sonnet spread to the rest of Italy. As it became more popular, more poets started writing them. One of the earliest and most important Italian sonnet writers was Francesco Petrarch. Petrarch’s sonnets helped make the sonnet famous across Europe. Petrarch changed the rhyme scheme slightly to ABBA ABBA CDCDCD
During the Renaissance, the sonnet spread into the rest of Europe, including England. When English poets first began writing sonnets, they found the Italian structure difficult to use because the English language has fewer rhyming words than Italian. The rhyme scheme was changed again to have less rhymes: ABAB CDCD EFEF GG
The most famous English sonnet writer is William Shakespeare. He wrote many sonnets, not just about love but also time, beauty, jealousy and death.
In modern times, poets still write sonnets, even though poetry has changed a lot. Some modern poets follow the traditional rules, while others have adapted it again. There are also now many English sonnets using the Petrarchan form.

_Poetry/Sonnet.title: Sonnet
_Poetry/Sonnet.content:
A white dove flies above the silent trees.
She dives and swoops but scarce meets with the ground.
But what to do if all you can believe
Is that this is what it will be like now?
The echoed past, I see it all around
As vivid light, but I float upwards now,
Not like before, I’m loosing touch with ground.
The sky feels happier than earth somehow.
But what if I was to head for the sky
And leave the ground, just leave it all behind?
The happiness and peace you can’t deny,
But then there is no room to change my mind.
But maybe ‘tween the sky and earth, a place;
Or maybe it’s a dream I cannot chase.
